element.definition: Parameter to store the search criteria
element.comment: The parameters that may be used are defined by the OperationDefinition resource.

element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comment: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content may not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content.
element.comment:
Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. 

This element is labelled as a modifier because the implicit rules may provide additional knowledge about the resource that modifies it's meaning or interpretation.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource  Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A parameter passed to or received from the operation.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
A parameter must have only one of (value, resource, part)
constraint.expression: (part.exists() and value.empty() and resource.empty()) or (part.empty() and (value.exists() xor resource.exists()))
constraint.xpath: exists(f:value) or exists(f:resource) and not(exists(f:value) and exists(f:resource))

element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.
element.comment: Note that FHIR strings may not exceed 1MB in size

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.definition: The identification of the code system that defines the meaning of the symbol in the code.
element.comment: The URI may be an OID (urn:oid:...) or a UUID (urn:uuid:...).  OIDs and UUIDs SHALL be references to the HL7 OID registry. Otherwise, the URI should come from HL7's list of FHIR defined special URIs or it should de-reference to some definition that establish the system clearly and unambiguously.
element.requirements: Need to be unambiguous about the source of the definition of the symbol.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Version of the system - if relevant
element.definition: The version of the code system which was used when choosing this code. Note that a well-maintained code system does not need the version reported, because the meaning of codes is consistent across versions. However this cannot consistently be assured. and when the meaning is not guaranteed to be consistent, the version SHOULD be exchanged.
element.comment: Where the terminology does not clearly define what string should be used to identify code system versions, the recommendation is to use the date (expressed in FHIR date format) on which that version was officially published as the version date.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Symbol in syntax defined by the system
element.definition: A symbol in syntax defined by the system. The symbol may be a predefined code or an expression in a syntax defined by the coding system (e.g. post-coordination).
element.comment: Note that FHIR strings may not exceed 1MB in size
element.requirements: Need to refer to a particular code in the system.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A representation of the meaning of the code in the system, following the rules of the system.
element.comment: Note that FHIR strings may not exceed 1MB in size
element.requirements: Need to be able to carry a human-readable meaning of the code for readers that do not know  the system.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: C*E.2 - but note this is not well followed

element.short: If this coding was chosen directly by the user
element.definition: Indicates that this coding was chosen by a user directly - i.e. off a pick list of available items (codes or displays).
element.comment: Amongst a set of alternatives, a directly chosen code is the most appropriate starting point for new translations. There is some ambiguity about what exactly 'directly chosen' implies, and trading partner agreement may be needed to clarify the use of this element and its consequences more completely.
element.requirements: This has been identified as a clinical safety criterium - that this exact system/code pair was chosen explicitly, rather than inferred by the system based on some rules or language processing.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:mapsTo dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:hasMap fhir:Coding.userSelected.map. fhir:Coding.userSelected.map a fhir:Map;   fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected\#true a [     fhir:source "true";     fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale\#O   ]

element.short: The SNOMED Concept ID supported by the Service.

element.comment: Where the terminology does not clearly define what string should be used to identify code system versions, the recommendation is to use the date (expressed in FHIR date format) on which that version was officially published as the version date.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Symbol in syntax defined by the system
element.definition: A symbol in syntax defined by the system. The symbol may be a predefined code or an expression in a syntax defined by the coding system (e.g. post-coordination).
element.comment: Note that FHIR strings may not exceed 1MB in size
element.requirements: Need to refer to a particular code in the system.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A representation of the meaning of the code in the system, following the rules of the system.
element.comment: Note that FHIR strings may not exceed 1MB in size
element.requirements: Need to be able to carry a human-readable meaning of the code for readers that do not know  the system.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: C*E.2 - but note this is not well followed

element.short: If this coding was chosen directly by the user
element.definition: Indicates that this coding was chosen by a user directly - i.e. off a pick list of available items (codes or displays).
element.comment: Amongst a set of alternatives, a directly chosen code is the most appropriate starting point for new translations. There is some ambiguity about what exactly 'directly chosen' implies, and trading partner agreement may be needed to clarify the use of this element and its consequences more completely.
element.requirements: This has been identified as a clinical safety criterium - that this exact system/code pair was chosen explicitly, rather than inferred by the system based on some rules or language processing.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The purpose of this identifier.
element.comment: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary id for a permanent one. Applications can assume that an identifier is permanent unless it explicitly says that it is temporary.
element.requirements: Allows the appropriate identifier for a particular context of use to be selected from among a set of identifiers.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Identifies the purpose for this identifier, if known .

element.definition: A coded type for the identifier that can be used to determine which identifier to use for a specific purpose.
element.comment:
This element deals only with general categories of identifiers.  It SHOULD not be used for codes that correspond 1..1 with the Identifier.system. Some identifiers may fall into multiple categories due to common usage. 

Where the system is known, a type is unnecessary because the type is always part of the system definition. However systems often need to handle identifiers where the system is not known. There is not a 1:1 relationship between type and system, since many different systems have the same type.
element.requirements: Allows users to make use of identifiers when the identifier system is not known.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: A coded type for an identifier that can be used to determine which identifier to use for a specific purpose.

element.short: The namespace for the identifier value
element.definition: Establishes the namespace for the value - that is, a URL that describes a set values that are unique.
element.comment: see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uniform_resource_identifier
element.requirements: There are many sets  of identifiers.  To perform matching of two identifiers, we need to know what set we're dealing with. The system identifies a particular set of unique identifiers.

example.label: General
example.valueUri: http://www.acme.com/identifiers/patient or urn:ietf:rfc:3986 if the Identifier.value itself is a full uri

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The portion of the identifier typically relevant to the user and which is unique within the context of the system.
element.comment: If the value is a full URI, then the system SHALL be urn:ietf:rfc:3986.  The value's primary purpose is computational mapping.  As a result, it may be normalized for comparison purposes (e.g. removing non-significant whitespace, dashes, etc.)  A value formatted for human display can be conveyed using the [Rendered Value extension](extension-rendered-value.html).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: II.extension or II.root if system indicates OID or GUID (Or Role.id.extension or root)

element.short: Time period when id is/was valid for use
element.definition: Time period during which identifier is/was valid for use.
element.comment: This is not a duration - that's a measure of time (a separate type), but a duration that occurs at a fixed value of time. A Period specifies a range of time; the context of use will specify whether the entire range applies (e.g. "the patient was an inpatient of the hospital for this time range") or one value from the range applies (e.g. "give to the patient between these two times"). If duration is required, specify the type as Interval|Duration.

element.short: This filter allows to select Services that are on the Primary Care/Secondary Care menus, or both.
element.definition: The value ALL_SERVICES is not valid for a Patient Service Search as it only applies to DoS Search.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
A parameter must have only one of (value, resource, part)
constraint.expression: (part.exists() and value.empty() and resource.empty()) or (part.empty() and (value.exists() xor resource.exists()))
constraint.xpath: exists(f:value) or exists(f:resource) and not(exists(f:value) and exists(f:resource))

element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.
element.comment: Note that FHIR strings may not exceed 1MB in size

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

element.definition: The identification of the code system that defines the meaning of the symbol in the code.
element.comment: The URI may be an OID (urn:oid:...) or a UUID (urn:uuid:...).  OIDs and UUIDs SHALL be references to the HL7 OID registry. Otherwise, the URI should come from HL7's list of FHIR defined special URIs or it should de-reference to some definition that establish the system clearly and unambiguously.
element.requirements: Need to be unambiguous about the source of the definition of the symbol.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Version of the system - if relevant
element.definition: The version of the code system which was used when choosing this code. Note that a well-maintained code system does not need the version reported, because the meaning of codes is consistent across versions. However this cannot consistently be assured. and when the meaning is not guaranteed to be consistent, the version SHOULD be exchanged.
element.comment: Where the terminology does not clearly define what string should be used to identify code system versions, the recommendation is to use the date (expressed in FHIR date format) on which that version was officially published as the version date.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Symbol in syntax defined by the system
element.definition: A symbol in syntax defined by the system. The symbol may be a predefined code or an expression in a syntax defined by the coding system (e.g. post-coordination).
element.comment: Note that FHIR strings may not exceed 1MB in size
element.requirements: Need to refer to a particular code in the system.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A representation of the meaning of the code in the system, following the rules of the system.
element.comment: Note that FHIR strings may not exceed 1MB in size
element.requirements: Need to be able to carry a human-readable meaning of the code for readers that do not know  the system.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: C*E.2 - but note this is not well followed

element.short: If this coding was chosen directly by the user
element.definition: Indicates that this coding was chosen by a user directly - i.e. off a pick list of available items (codes or displays).
element.comment: Amongst a set of alternatives, a directly chosen code is the most appropriate starting point for new translations. There is some ambiguity about what exactly 'directly chosen' implies, and trading partner agreement may be needed to clarify the use of this element and its consequences more completely.
element.requirements: This has been identified as a clinical safety criterium - that this exact system/code pair was chosen explicitly, rather than inferred by the system based on some rules or language processing.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:mapsTo dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:hasMap fhir:Coding.userSelected.map. fhir:Coding.userSelected.map a fhir:Map;   fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected\#true a [     fhir:source "true";     fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale\#O   ]

element.definition: Parameter to store the search criteria
Search criteria.
search criteria specialty.

element.short: The Clinic Type within the Specialty selected.
element.definition: The Clinic Type within the Specialty selected.

element.short: The SNOMED Concept ID supported by the Service.
element.definition:
The SNOMED Concept ID supported by the Service. The SCTID must be at level 2 or above.
The system should be set to http://snomed.info/sct

element.short: The Named Clinician for the Service.
element.definition:
It must be a user that is active in SDS and with Service Provider Clinician role.
If supplied, the identifier must be in valid SDS format, i.e. ^[0-9]{12}$

element.short: The Service Location or Service Provding Organisation for the Service.
element.definition: The Service Location or Service Provding Organisation for the Service.
Indicative appointment wait time limit. Range: 0-999 interpreted as 'days'.

Must be in one of the following formats:
AA9A 9AA
A9A 9AA
A9 9AA
A99 9AA
AA9 9AA
AA99 9AA
Where âAâ represents a letter, and â9â represents a digit.

Range: 0-999
Only applicable if a Postcode was specified. 
Zero is an admissible value and filters services which are less than 1 mile away.

element.short: Filters the Services based on the Gender and Age derived from the Patient Record.
element.definition: Filters the Services based on the Gender and Age derived from the Patient Record.

element.definition: The value ALL_SERVICES is not valid for a Patient Service Search as it only applies to DoS Search.
